Award.AwardTitle: Topics in Low Dimensional Geometric Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Numerous advances in topology have arisen from applications of ideas from geometry and dynamics. This project aims to continue this line of investigation. More specifically, we aim to study 3-manifolds, harmonic maps, and Riemann surfaces. The study of 3-manifolds is in essence the study of the possible shapes of the universe and as such sits naturally at the intersection of mathematics and theoretical physics. Surfaces are two-dimensional spaces like the surface of a ball or a doughnut. Their topological and geometric properties have been extensively studied and this research lies at the intersection of all fields of mathematics. The parameter space of all geometric structures on a given surface is called the moduli space. We study moduli spaces because to understand one particular structure on a space we must understand the structure of the space of all structures. Theory of harmonic maps originates in the theory of minimal surfaces. It aims to establish important properties of harmonic maps which in turn provide useful information about minimal surfaces like the physical description of a soap film spanning a wire boundary.


The principal investigator will study geometry of Teichmueller spaces, existence of equivariant harmonic maps for surface group representations, maps from surfaces into 3-manifolds, and the solutions of the 2D-Euler equation for incompressible fluids. The main goals are to: Classify Teichmueller discs where the Caratheodory and Teichmueller metrics agree; To build on the proof of the Schoen conjecture and establish results about the existence of equivariant harmonic maps corresponding to representations of the fundamental groups of compact surfaces with boundary and of surfaces of infinite rank; To investigate the simple loop conjecture for hyperbolic 3-manifolds; To consider whether the gradient of the vorticity in the 2D-Euler equation can achieve the double exponential growth.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Caratheodory metric on a complex manifold is the smallest holomorphically natural metric (the largest being the Kobayashi metric). These two metrics agree on locally symmetric complex spaces (as shown by Kobayashi).  A cornerstone result in Teichmuller theory is the theorem of Royden that the Teichmuller metric agrees with the Kobayashi metric on a Teichm\"uller space. It remained an open problem (since the 1960's) to determine whether the Caratheodory metric agrees with the Teichmuller metric. I resolved this problem by showing that the Caratheodory and the Teichmuller metrics do not agree on any Teichmuller space of dimension at least two. Using this result I also proved the Siu's conjecture that  Teichmuller spaces  are not biholomorphic to  convex domains in the complex space of dimension 3g-3.  


The Nielsen realization problem for the mapping class group Mod(S) asks whether the natural projection p: Homeo(S) --> Mod(S) has a section. While all the previous results use torsion elements in an essential way,  Lei Chen and I were focusing on the  more difficult problem of realization of torsion-free subgroups of Mod(S).  We proved  the following theorem  using new approach to the problem that revolves around the Poinc\'are-Birkhoff theorem: The Torelli group cannot be realized as a group of area-preserving homeomorphisms of a surface of genus greater than five.

Together with Oleg Ivrii, I have initiated an approach to study Random Quasiconformal Maps and their geometry. We solve two problems dealing with the homogenization of random media. We show that a random quasiconformal mapping is close to an affine mapping, while a circle packing of a random Delauney triangulation is close to a conformal map, confirming a conjecture of K. Stephenson. We also show that on a Riemann surface equipped with a conformal metric, a random Delauney triangulation is close to being circle packed.
